title: Agile Team Formation & Dynamics
description: Master optimal Agile team composition, understand Tuckman's stages, and interpret velocity for team health.
objectives: Apply the 7±2 rule for optimal Agile team size (5-9 members)
Recognize Tuckman's four stages: Forming, Storming, Norming, Performing
Understand that velocity is team-specific (cannot compare across teams)
Build cross-functional teams with all skills needed to deliver increments
Recognize that Agile teams need collocated or high-bandwidth communication
Identify when velocity drops indicate team composition issues vs workflow problems

screens.headline: Velocity Drops 40%: Is the Team Too Big or Just Dysfunctional?

dialogue.text: Menu Lab added 4 members to speed things up. Velocity dropped 40%. Morgan says 'team's too big.' Alex says 'they're still forming.' Who's right?

screens.learningHook: You'll learn: optimal team size (7±2 rule), Tuckman's stages, velocity interpretation, cross-functional composition, and communication channels explosion.

screens.title: Solve the Team Composition Crisis
screens.instructions: 3 scenarios test team formation principles. Select the Agile principle AND recommended action for each.

scenarios.title: Team Size & Velocity Drop
description: Sprint 4-5: Added 4 members (now 12), velocity dropped to 27 points/sprint (-40%)
Carlos: 'We added people to go faster. Why did velocity drop?'

questions.question: What Agile principle explains the velocity drop?

options.text: Optimal team size is 7±2 (5-9 members). 12 members exceeds optimal range → communication overhead increases
New members are inexperienced → need training before contributing
Velocity naturally fluctuates ± 20% → 40% drop is normal variation
Team needs more time to learn estimation → velocity will stabilize after 3 sprints

feedback.correct: Correct! 7±2 rule: 5-9 members is optimal. 12 members = communication channels explosion. Too many people = more coordination overhead, less actual work.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. Primary issue is team SIZE. 12 members exceeds 7±2 optimal range. Communication channels = n(n-1)/2. 8 members = 28 channels. 12 members = 66 channels (+135% overhead).

questions.question: How should Alex respond to the velocity drop?

options.text: Split into 2 teams: 6 members each (both within 7±2 optimal range)
Keep 12-member team, add more tools for coordination
Remove 4 new members (return to original 8)
Wait 3 sprints for velocity to stabilize (new members need time)

feedback.correct: Perfect! Split into 2 teams of 6 (both within optimal 5-9 range). Reduces communication overhead, maintains Agile principles.
feedback.incorrect: Not optimal. Tools don't solve fundamental communication overhead. Split team to bring both within 7±2 optimal range.

scenarios.title: Tuckman's Storming Stage
description: Week 3: Team argues over technical decisions, Maya and Devon clash on framework choice
Taylor: 'This is normal—Storming stage. Team will work through it.'
Morgan: 'This dysfunction is unacceptable. We need to replace conflicting members.'

questions.question: What Tuckman stage is the team in?

options.text: Forming (getting to know each other, polite)
Storming (conflict, establishing norms, working through disagreements)
Norming (cohesion, established processes, smoother collaboration)
Performing (high efficiency, self-organizing, peak productivity)

feedback.correct: Correct! Storming = conflict, disagreements, establishing norms. This is NORMAL and necessary. Teams must storm before they can norm and perform.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. Conflict and disagreements = Storming stage. This is normal team development—not dysfunction. Don't skip Storming.

questions.question: How should Alex respond to the conflict?

options.text: Replace Maya or Devon (remove conflicting members)
Facilitate conflict resolution, let team work through disagreements (Storming is normal)
Mandate technical decisions to eliminate conflict
Separate Maya and Devon into different teams

feedback.correct: Excellent! Facilitate conflict resolution, don't eliminate conflict. Storming is necessary for team development. Coach team through disagreements.
feedback.incorrect: Not optimal. Storming is NORMAL. Don't remove members or separate them. Facilitate healthy conflict resolution—team needs to work through this.

scenarios.title: Velocity Comparison Trap
description: Carlos: 'Team A velocity is 45 points/sprint. Team B velocity is 30 points/sprint. Team B is underperforming!'
Alex: 'You can't compare velocity across teams—different estimation baselines, team composition, work complexity.'

questions.question: Can you compare velocity across different Agile teams?

options.text: Yes—velocity is a standard metric (like revenue or cost)
No—velocity is team-specific (different estimation baselines, cannot compare)
Yes, if teams use same estimation method (Planning Poker, T-shirt sizing)
Yes, if you normalize for team size (velocity per team member)

feedback.correct: Correct! Velocity is TEAM-SPECIFIC. Different teams estimate differently. One team's '3 points' ≠ another team's '3 points'. Cannot compare.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. Velocity is NOT comparable across teams. Each team has unique estimation baseline. Comparing velocity creates false competition and gaming metrics.

questions.question: How should Alex respond to Carlos's velocity comparison?

options.text: Agree—Team B needs to improve velocity to match Team A
Explain velocity is team-specific, use trend analysis instead (is Team B improving over time?)
Normalize velocity (divide by team size) to make teams comparable
Re-estimate both teams' backlogs with same baseline

feedback.correct: Perfect! Educate on velocity interpretation. Track trends WITHIN each team (is velocity improving?), not ACROSS teams. Focus on value delivered.
feedback.incorrect: Not optimal. Velocity is NOT comparable across teams. Normalizing or re-estimating doesn't solve this—focus on within-team trends.

content.principle: Optimal Agile team size is 7±2 members (5-9 people). Too small = skill gaps. Too large = communication overhead.

rationale.communicationChannels: Communication channels = n(n-1)/2. 5 members = 10 channels. 9 members = 36 channels. 12 members = 66 channels (+83% vs 9).
rationale.coordinationCost: More channels = more coordination meetings, more conflicts, less actual work. Diminishing returns beyond 9 members.

examples.note: Minimum viable team—risk of skill gaps

content.insight: When team grows beyond 9, SPLIT into 2 teams. Don't add coordination tools—reduce team size.
content.pmbokRef: Agile Practice Guide page 41; Essential Scrum page 103

stages.name: Forming
stages.description: Team members get to know each other. Polite, cautious, establishing roles.

stages.name: Storming
stages.description: Conflict emerges as team establishes norms. Disagreements on processes, technical decisions.
stages.note: NORMAL and NECESSARY. Don't skip this stage.

stages.name: Norming
stages.description: Team develops cohesion, agrees on processes, smoother collaboration.

stages.name: Performing
stages.description: High efficiency, self-organizing, peak productivity. Team operates smoothly.

content.insight: Don't expect new teams to Perform immediately. Storming is NECESSARY—teams that skip it never fully develop. Leadership during Storming: facilitate, don't eliminate conflict.
content.pmbokRef: PMBOK 7th page 169; Agile Practice Guide page 42

principles.explanation: Cannot compare velocity ACROSS teams. Each team has unique estimation baseline. One team's 3 points ≠ another team's 3 points.
Track WITHIN-team trends. Is Team A's velocity improving over time? That's meaningful. Comparing Team A to Team B is not.
High velocity with low-value features is worse than low velocity with high-value features. Focus on value delivered, not points completed.
New teams have volatile velocity (learning estimation). After 3-5 sprints, velocity stabilizes and becomes useful for sprint planning.

traps: Comparing velocity across teams (creates false competition)
Using velocity for individual performance (velocity is team metric)
Pressuring teams to increase velocity (leads to point inflation)
Normalizing velocity by team size (still not comparable)
content.insight: Velocity is a PLANNING tool (how much work can we commit to?), not a PERFORMANCE metric (how good is this team?).

content.definition: Cross-functional team has ALL skills needed to deliver a potentially shippable product increment—no external dependencies.
benefits: Faster delivery (no waiting for external teams)
Better collaboration (all expertise in one team)
content.antipattern: Component teams (UI team, Backend team, QA team) create dependencies, handoffs, delays. Cross-functional feature teams are faster.

correct.text: 12 members exceeds 7±2 optimal range. Communication overhead exploded. Split into 2 teams of 6—both within optimal size. Velocity will recover.

incorrect.text: I thought more people = faster delivery. But communication overhead kills productivity. Optimal is 7±2 members. We need to split the team.

correct.text: Storming is NORMAL. Team is establishing norms, working through disagreements. Don't eliminate conflict—facilitate healthy resolution. This is necessary development.
Velocity is team-specific—cannot compare across teams. Track trends WITHIN each team. Focus on value delivered, not points completed.

screens.title: New Challenge: Distributed Team Formation
screens.context: Menu Lab must work with remote members: 3 in NYC, 2 in Denver, 2 in London. Apply team formation principles to distributed context.

options.text: Yes—within 7±2 range regardless of location
No—distributed teams should be smaller (5 max)
No—distributed teams should be larger (10+) to cover time zones

feedback.correct: Correct! 7±2 rule applies regardless of location. 7 members is optimal size. Location adds communication challenges but doesn't change optimal size.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. 7±2 rule applies to distributed teams too. Location doesn't change optimal team size—just adds communication coordination needs.

questions.question: Distributed team velocity is 30% lower than collocated. What's likely cause?

options.text: Remote members are less productive
Communication overhead (time zones, lower bandwidth)
Team needs better tools (Slack, Zoom)

feedback.correct: Correct! Distributed teams have higher communication overhead (time zones, lower-bandwidth communication vs face-to-face). This reduces velocity—normal tradeoff.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. Primary issue is communication overhead, not productivity or tools. Distributed teams have inherently higher coordination costs.

questions.question: Should distributed team use same estimation baseline as collocated team?

options.text: Yes—ensures consistency across organization
No—each team establishes own estimation baseline

feedback.correct: Correct! Each team establishes own estimation baseline. Distributed team's '5 points' may differ from collocated team's '5 points'—and that's OK.
feedback.incorrect: WRONG. Velocity is team-specific. Don't force common estimation baseline across teams—each team calibrates independently.

screens.title: Key Takeaways: Agile Team Formation
screens.summary: You've learned optimal team size (7±2), Tuckman's stages (Forming, Storming, Norming, Performing), velocity interpretation (team-specific, not comparable), and cross-functional team composition.
takeaways: Optimal team size: 7±2 members (5-9). Too large = communication overhead. Split into 2 teams if > 9.
Communication channels = n(n-1)/2. 12 members = 66 channels vs 8 members = 28 channels (+135% overhead).
Tuckman's stages: Forming → Storming → Norming → Performing. Storming is NORMAL and NECESSARY.
Don't skip Storming. Facilitate conflict resolution, don't eliminate conflict.
Velocity is team-specific. Cannot compare across teams. Use for within-team trend analysis only.
Don't use velocity for performance evaluation. It's a planning tool, not productivity metric.
Cross-functional teams have all skills needed—no external dependencies, faster delivery.
Velocity stabilizes after 3-5 sprints. New teams have volatile velocity (learning estimation).
